column3:
Karol A. Penson (1 and 2) and Allan I. Solomon (1 and 2)((1) LPTL,
  University of Paris VI, France (2) Quantum Processes Group, Open University,
  UK)
column4: Coherent State Measures and the Extended Dobinski relations
column5:
PDF. 10 Pages. Proceedings of the Seventh International School of
  Theoretical Physics "Symmetry and Structural Properties of Condensed Matter "
  (SSPCM 2002), Myczkowce, Poland,11-18 Sept. 2002 Editors: T.Lulek and A.Wal
  (in press)
column11:
Conventional Bell and Stirling numbers arise naturally in the normal ordering
of simple monomials in boson operators. By extending this process we obtain
generalizations of these combinatorial numbers, defined as coherent state
matrix elements of arbitrary monomials, as well as the associated Dobinski
relations. These Bell-type numbers may be considered as power moments and give
rise to positive measures which allow the explicit construction of new classes
of coherent states.

column3: Denis D. Sheka, Boris A. Ivanov, and Franz G. Mertens
column4:
Asymptotic phase shifts and Levinson theorem for 2D potentials with
  inverse square singularities
column5: 16 pages (REVTeX)
column11:
The Levinson theorem for two-dimensional scattering is generalized for
potentials with inverse square singularities. By this theorem, the number of
bound states in a given m-th partial wave is related to the phase shift and the
singularity strength of the potential. For the m-wave phase shift the
asymptotic behaviour is calculated for short wavelengths.

column3: Sixia Yu, Zeng-Bing Chen, Jian-Wei Pan, and Yong-De Zhang
column4: Classifying N-qubit Entanglement via Bell's Inequalities
column5: 4 pages, 3 figures
column11:
All the states of N qubits can be classified into N-1 entanglement classes
from 2-entangled to N-entangled (fully entangled) states. Each class of
entangled states is characterized by an entanglement index that depends on the
partition of N. The larger the entanglement index of an state, the more
entangled or the less separable is the state in the sense that a larger maximal
violation of Bell's inequality is attainable for this class of state.

column3: Pekka Lahti
column4: Coexistence and Joint Measurability in Quantum Mechanics
column5:
A lecture presented at Quantum Composite Systems 2002, Ustron,
  Poland, 3.-7.9.2002
column11:
This talk is a survey of the question of joint measurability of coexistent
observables and its is based on the monograph Operational Quantum Physics [1]
and on the papers [2,3,4].

column3: H. Failache, P. Valente, G. Ban, V. Lorent and A. Lezama
column4:
Inhibition of electromagnetically induced absorption due to excited
  state decoherence in Rb vapor
column5: 8 pages, 7 figures, submitted to Physical Review A
column11:
The explanation presented in [Taichenachev et al, Phys. Rev. A {\bf 61},
011802 (2000)] according to which the electromagnetically induced absorption
(EIA) resonances observed in degenerate two level systems are due to coherence
transfer from the excited to the ground state is experimentally tested in a
Hanle type experiment observing the parametric resonance on the $% D1$ line of
$^{87}$Rb. While EIA occurs in the $F=1\to F^{\prime}=2 $ transition in a cell
containing only $Rb$ vapor, collisions with a buffer gas ($30 torr$ of $Ne$)
cause the sign reversal of this resonance as a consequence of collisional
decoherence of the excited state. A theoretical model in good qualitative
agreement with the experimental results is presented.

column3:
Wolfgang Alt, Dominik Schrader, Stefan Kuhr, Martin Mueller, Victor
  Gomer, Dieter Meschede
column4: Single atoms in a standing-wave dipole trap
column5: 8 pages, 7 figures, submitted to Phys. Rev. A
column11:
We trap a single cesium atom in a standing-wave optical dipole trap. Special
experimental procedures, designed to work with single atoms, are used to
measure the oscillation frequency and the atomic energy distribution in the
dipole trap. These methods rely on unambiguously detecting presence or loss of
the atom using its resonance fluorescence in the magneto-optical trap.

column3:
J\'erome Wenger, Mohammad Hafezi, Fr\'ed\'eric Grosshans, Rosa
  Tualle-Brouri and Philippe Grangier
column4:
Maximal Violation of Bell Inequalities using Continuous Variables
  Measurements
column5: 7 pages, 5 figures, to appear in PRA in a slightly different version
column11:
We propose a whole family of physical states that yield a violation of the
Bell CHSH inequality arbitrarily close to its maximum value, when using
quadrature phase homodyne detection. This result is based on a new binning
process called root binning, that is used to transform the continuous variables
measurements into binary results needed for the tests of quantum mechanics
versus local realistic theories. A physical process in order to produce such
states is also suggested. The use of high-efficiency spacelike separated
homodyne detections with these states and this binning process would result in
a conclusive loophole-free test of quantum mechanics.
